commander.name: Major-General John Harding
commander.previous_service: Brought in by Lieutenant-General Bernard Montgomery. Led division through El Alamein and pursuit across Libya. Wounded by shell while leading from front in December 1942.

command.headquarters_location: Mobile HQ, Western Desert - Libya (pursuit from El Alamein to El Agheila)

M4 Sherman.note: 75mm gun, assigned to 7th Armoured Division at El Alamein

Water bowser.role: Water supply - critical for desert operations

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.note: Two field regiments (24 guns each) - 3rd RHA and 5th RHA

supply_logistics.supply_status: Stretched but adequate for pursuit operations. Main constraint: fuel and water delivery over 1,800km from Alexandria. Supply lines lengthening daily as division pursues Axis forces westward across Libya. Benghazi port captured but not yet operational. Tobruk supply base 400km to rear. Priority: fuel for tanks and water for personnel in desert pursuit.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (Libyan Desert west of Tobruk)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Royal Tank Regiment (RTR), 5th RTR, 4th County of London Yeomanry (CLY/Sharpshooters), 1st Rifle Brigade (Motor Battalion)
subordinate_units.notes: Main striking force. Joined 7th Armoured Division October 1942. Equipped with Sherman, Grant, Crusader, and Stuart tanks.

subordinate_units.composition: Royal Scots Greys, 4th/8th Hussars (composite regiment), 2nd Derbyshire Yeomanry (reconnaissance)
subordinate_units.notes: Reconnaissance and flank protection. 4th and 8th Hussars temporarily amalgamated. Primarily Stuart light tanks and armoured cars.

subordinate_units.composition: 1/5th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/6th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/7th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment
subordinate_units.notes: Motor infantry component. Joined 7th Armoured Division for El Alamein. Three battalions of Queen's Royal Regiment. Provided infantry support for armoured operations.
Self-propelled artillery support. Highly mobile field regiment attached to armoured division.
Second field artillery regiment. Mobile fire support for armoured operations.

subordinate_units.composition: Multiple anti-tank batteries with 6-pounder and 2-pounder guns
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional anti-tank defense. Mix of towed and portee-mounted guns.
Air defense for division. Mobile Bofors batteries.

subordinate_units.composition: Communications squadrons, wireless sections, line sections
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional communications network. Critical for coordination during mobile operations.

subordinate_units.composition: Field squadrons, workshop sections, bridging sections
subordinate_units.notes: Mine clearance, bridging, demolitions. Critical for pursuit operations across Libya.

subordinate_units.composition: Transport companies, supply columns, petrol company, water company
subordinate_units.notes: Royal Army Service Corps. Logistics tail supporting extended pursuit operations.

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured exploitation force. Specialized in wide flanking movements, pursuit operations, and reconnaissance in force. 'Desert Rats' nickname earned through aggressive armoured warfare in North African campaign.
special_capabilities: Extended desert operations with minimal supply
tactical_innovations: Mixed tank squadrons (Sherman/Grant heavy + Stuart light)
Motor infantry battalion integration with armoured brigades
Mobile artillery support using portee-mounted guns
Radio net coordination for dispersed operations
known_issues: Extended supply lines during pursuit (1800km from Alexandria)
Tank mechanical reliability during high-tempo operations
Fuel and water constraints limiting operational radius
Mixed tank types complicating maintenance and logistics
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive desert warfare modifications: sun compasses, sand channels, condensers for water recovery, extra water and fuel stowage, desert camouflage patterns, goggles and respirators for dust storms, specialized navigation training. Unit pioneered desert warfare tactics 1940-1942.

special_rules: Desert Rats: +1 morale in desert terrain
Pursuit Operations: +10% movement rate during exploitation phase
Combined Arms Excellence: Artillery support missions resolve one phase faster
Extended Supply Lines: -1 to supply rolls if >200km from depot
Tank Gunnery: +5% hit probability for Sherman and Grant tanks
Night Movement: No penalty for night movement in desert
Reconnaissance Excellence: +15% spotting range for armoured car units
historical_engagements: Second Battle of El Alamein (23 October - 11 November 1942)
Pursuit to Fuka and Mersa Matruh (November 1942)

validation.notes: Data compiled from multiple sources including organizational tables, battle reports, and unit histories. Tank numbers based on August 1942 Middle East armoured division establishment (172 tanks) with types reflecting El Alamein/pursuit period allocations. Personnel strength estimated at 14,850 based on standard British armoured division establishment. Supply/logistics data reflects historical accounts of extended pursuit operations across Libya with 1800km supply line from Alexandria.
